P.title: Will NASA's Orion capsule complete a crewed return mission from the ISS by August 2024?
P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, NASA's Orion capsule successfully completes a crewed return mission from the International Space Station (ISS) to Earth. For a positive resolution:

1. The mission must involve the Orion capsule transporting at least one human crew member from the ISS back to Earth.
2. The capsule must land safely with all crew members in good health.
3. The mission's success must be officially confirmed by NASA or another authoritative space agency.
4. The confirmation must be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, CNN, New York Times).

The question will resolve as NO if:
- No such mission occurs by the specified date.
- A mission is attempted but fails to meet all the above criteria.
- The Orion capsule is used only for uncrewed missions or launches to the ISS without a return flight.

Note: This question does not consider test flights or simulations. Only actual crewed return missions from the ISS count towards resolution.

Confirmation must come from at least one of the following sources: Sudanese health authorities, the World Health Organization (WHO), or reputable international news agencies (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC) citing official figures. The death toll must be specifically attributed to the cholera outbreak that began in 2023. If the number of confirmed cholera-related deaths in Sudan remains at 50 or fewer by the resolution date, or if no reliable data is available, the question resolves as NO.

The question asks whether Sudan will report over 50 cholera-related deaths by August 2024. Given the resolution date of August 31, 2024, and considering the information available, we can assess the situation.

However, since this report includes data beyond the resolution date, we primarily rely on the earlier report for our conclusion.

    Given this information, it is clear that the number of cholera-related deaths in Sudan exceeded 50 by the resolution date.

P.title: Will Russia report a bumper harvest for both wheat and sunflowers by August 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Russia officially reports a bumper harvest for both wheat and sunflowers, indicating higher than average yields compared to the previous five-year average. A bumper harvest is defined as a crop yield that is significantly above average, typically at least 10% higher than the five-year average. Confirmation must come from official reports by the Russian Ministry of Agriculture or at least three reputable news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or TASS). P.title: Will the WHO declare the polio outbreak in Afghanistan no longer a global emergency by August 2024?
P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares that the polio outbreak in Afghanistan is no longer considered a global emergency. For a YES resolution:

1. The WHO must make a public announcement explicitly stating that the polio outbreak in Afghanistan is no longer a global emergency.
2. This declaration must be reported by at least two major international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN).
3. The declaration must specifically refer to the Afghan polio outbreak, not a global polio situation in general.

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. The WHO does not make such a declaration by August 31, 2024.
2. The WHO makes a declaration about polio that does not specifically address the Afghan outbreak.
3. The WHO maintains or escalates the emergency status of the Afghan polio outbreak.

Note: If the WHO has already declared the Afghan polio outbreak no longer a global emergency prior to this question's start date, the question will still resolve based on the status as of August 31, 2024.

P.title: Will the WHO declare the cholera outbreak in Yemen no longer a global emergency by August 2024?
P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares that the cholera outbreak in Yemen is no longer considered a global emergency. For a YES resolution:

1. The WHO must make a public announcement explicitly stating that the cholera outbreak in Yemen is no longer a global emergency.
2. This declaration must be reported by at least two major international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN).
3. The declaration must specifically refer to the Yemeni cholera outbreak, not a global cholera situation in general.

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. The WHO does not make such a declaration by August 31, 2024.
2. The WHO makes a declaration about cholera that does not specifically address the Yemeni outbreak.
3. The WHO maintains or escalates the emergency status of the Yemeni cholera outbreak.

Note: If the WHO has already declared the Yemeni cholera outbreak no longer a global emergency prior to this question's start date, the question will still resolve based on the status as of August 31, 2024.

2. There must be no reports by at least two major international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN) of such a declaration.
3. Any declaration made must not specifically refer to the Yemeni cholera outbreak as no longer being a global emergency.

The question will resolve as NO if:
1. The WHO makes such a declaration by August 31, 2024.

3. The WHO does not maintain or escalate the emergency status of the Yemeni cholera outbreak.

    1. **The FCC adopted a Declaratory Ruling, Order, Report and Order, and Order on Reconsideration on April 25, 2024, restoring Net Neutrality and bringing back a national standard for broadband reliability, security, and consumer protection.**
    2. **The final rule was published in the Federal Register on May 22, 2024, establishing an effective date of July 22, 2024.**
    3. **However, the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals issued an order to temporarily stay the FCC's net neutrality final rule from going into effect on July 22, 2024. The stay was in place through August 5, 2024.**

    Given these points, the FCC did attempt to reinstate net neutrality rules, but the implementation was temporarily stayed by the court. Since the stay was only through August 5, 2024, and the question's resolution date is August 31, 2024, we need to consider whether the rule was effectively reinstated after the stay was lifted.

    **Update as of August 8, 2024:** The U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit is still reviewing the consolidated petitions for review of the FCC's Open Internet Order. The court granted petitioners' motion to stay pending review, indicating that the petitioners were likely to succeed on the merits of their challenge to the Order. This means the rule's reinstatement is still pending legal review and not effectively reinstated as of the resolution date.

    Therefore, despite the FCC's efforts to reinstate net neutrality, the legal challenges and the court's stay mean the rule was not effectively reinstated by August 31, 2024.

article_information.article_content: WASHINGTON (AP) A federal appeals court has allowed the U.S. Education Department to move ahead with a plan to lower monthly payments for millions of student loan borrowers, putting on hold a ruling … [+2556 chars]

perplexity_verification.chain_of_thought:
To resolve this question, I've checked the following sources:
    1. Official government announcements and websites related to student loan policies.
    2. Major reputable news outlets including ABC News, The Sydney Morning Herald, and The Australian.

    The Australian government has proposed changes to the indexation amounts that apply to Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) student loans from 2023 onwards. Specifically, the government has decided to calculate the annual indexation based on the lesser of the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and the Wage Price Index (WPI), instead of solely on CPI. This change aims to prevent student debts from growing faster than wages.

    Education Minister Jason Clare announced that this change would "wipe out what happened last year and make sure it never happens again," referring to the high 7.1% indexation increase in 2023, which will be retroactively reduced to 3.2%.

    This policy change directly impacts the amount of debt owed by students and, by extension, can lower the monthly payments required to repay these loans. The implementation of this plan has been confirmed by official announcements and reported by major news outlets, such as ABC News.

    Given this information, it is clear that the Australian government has implemented a plan to lower student loan payments by changing the indexation method, which aligns with the criteria for resolving this question positively.

Oregon's current safe storage law, enacted in 2021, requires the owner or possessor of a firearm to secure the firearm when it is not carried by or under the control of the owner, possessor, or authorized person. This law specifies that firearms must be secured with an engaged trigger or cable lock, in a locked container, or in a gun room. The law also stipulates that a firearm is not considered secured if a key or combination to the trigger or cable lock or the container is readily available to an unauthorized person, or if the firearm is a handgun left unattended in a vehicle and within view of persons outside the vehicle.

    As of the latest available information up to June 2024, there is no indication that Oregon has repealed or significantly altered its safe storage requirement for firearms. The law remains in effect, and there are no reports or announcements from Oregon's government or reputable news sources suggesting a change to this regulation by August 2024.

    Given this information, it is reasonable to conclude that Oregon will maintain its safe storage requirement for firearms through August 2024.

P.title: Will the Central Bank of Turkey announce an interest rate cut by August 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Turkey officially announces an interest rate cut to take effect by August 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed by official Central Bank of Turkey communications, such as press releases, Monetary Policy Committee statements, or public speeches by Bank officials. P.title: Will SpaceX's Dragon capsule complete a crewed return mission from the ISS by August 2024?
P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, SpaceX's Dragon capsule successfully completes a crewed return mission from the International Space Station (ISS) to Earth. For a positive resolution:

1. The mission must involve the Dragon capsule transporting at least one human crew member from the ISS back to Earth.
2. The capsule must land safely with all crew members in good health.
3. The mission's success must be officially confirmed by NASA or another authoritative space agency.
4. The confirmation must be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, CNN, New York Times).

The question will resolve as NO if:
- No such mission occurs by the specified date.
- A mission is attempted but fails to meet all the above criteria.
- The Dragon capsule is used only for uncrewed missions or launches to the ISS without a return flight.

Note: This question does not consider test flights or simulations. Only actual crewed return missions from the ISS count towards resolution.
